newsitem.title: USA: Producer prices rose 0.4 percent in November.
newsitem.headline: Producer prices rose 0.4 percent in November.

text.p: Prices at the wholesale level rose in November, the Labor Department said Wednesday, as energy prices posted the biggest jump since April.
The department said the Producer Price Index rose 0.4 percent last month, matching the 0.4 percent increase in October.
The so-called core rate, which excludes the often volatile food and energy sectors, rose by 0.1 percent in November after a 0.3 percent decline in October.
Wall Street economists had forecast a 0.3 percent increase in wholesale prices overall and a 0.2 percent rise in the core rate.
Energy prices rose 2.3 percent, the biggest gain since a 2.7 percent increase in April, the department said. Energy prices had risen 1.9 percent in October.

Gasoline prices rose 2.8 percent, while heating oil prices fell 0.4 percent in November, the department said. Residential gas prices rose 3.8 percent, a record increase that exceeded the 3.4 percent gain recorded in December 1995, the department said.
Food prices fell 0.1 percent in November, the first decline since a 0.5 percent drop in April, the department said. Food prices had jumped 0.8 percent in October.

Fresh and dry vegetable prices rose 16.6 percent in November, as lettuce prices jumped 155.4 percent. Fresh fruit and melon prices fell 17.7 percent as the prices of navel oranges dropped 57.4 percent.
Passenger car prices rose 0.5 percent in November after falling 1.6 percent in October. Tobacco prices fell 0.1 percent last month, after rising 0.3 percent in October.

Prices of intermediate goods -- those that require further processing -- rose 0.2 percent after being unchanged in October. Prices of crude goods rose 1.8 percent after a 0.6 percent decline in October.
